title: Robert E. Withers
text:
Robert Enoch Withers (September 18, 1821September 21, 1907) was an American physician, <a href="officer%20%28armed%20forces%29">military officer</a>, newspaperman, politician diplomat, and <a href="Freemason">Freemason</a>. He represented <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a> in the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> and served as U.S. Consul in Hong Kong.
Biography.
Withers was born near <a href="Lynchburg%2C%20Virginia">Lynchburg, Virginia</a>. He attended private schools and then graduated from the medical department of the <a href="University%20of%20Virginia">University of Virginia</a> at <a href="Charlottesville%2C%20Virginia">Charlottesville</a> in 1841. He commenced practice in <a href="Campbell%20County%2C%20Virginia">Campbell County</a>. In 1858, Withers moved to <a href="Danville%2C%20Virginia">Danville, Virginia</a>. While studying at university, Withers was inducted into the freemasons, an organization that he would remain with for life, specifically as a leader in the <a href="Knights%20Templar">Knights Templar</a>.
During the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, he entered the <a href="Confederate%20States%20Army">Confederate Army</a> in early 1861 as the <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> of the <a href="18th%20Virginia%20Infantry">18th Virginia Infantry</a>. He was subsequently promoted to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> of the <a href="regiment">regiment</a>, which he commanded until retired because of numerous disabling wounds. He was then appointed to command the Confederate military post at Danville, an administrative position he held until the close of the war.
Following the Civil War, Withers moved back to Lynchburg in 1866 and established the "Lynchburg News", a daily paper devoted to the interests of the Conservative Party. He was nominated for <a href="Governor%20of%20Virginia">Governor of Virginia</a> by that party, but withdrew from the race. He was a presidential elector on the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic</a> ticket in 1872. He was elected the 11th <a href="Lieutenant%20Governor%20of%20Virginia">Lieutenant Governor of Virginia</a> in 1873. He was elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1875, to March 4, 1881. He served as the chairman of the Committee on Pensions in the <a href="46th%20United%20States%20Congress">46th Congress</a>. Withers was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1881, losing to former Civil War general <a href="William%20Mahone">William Mahone</a> of the <a href="Readjuster%20Party">Readjuster Party</a>.
He was appointed by President <a href="Grover%20Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> as the United States consul at <a href="British%20Hong%20Kong">British Hong Kong</a>, from 1885–89, when he resigned. He returned to the United States and retired to <a href="Wytheville%2C%20Virginia">Wytheville, Virginia</a>. During his retirement, he comprised his personal autobiography, "Memoirs of an Octogenarian". He was a distant relative of figures such as <a href="George%20Washington">George Washington</a> and <a href="Robert%20E.%20Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>, as well as a direct descendant of <a href="Nicolas%20Martiau">Nicolas Martiau</a>, founder of <a href="Yorktown%2C%20Virginia">Yorktown, Virginia</a>.
Withers died at the "Ingleside" <a href="plantations%20in%20the%20American%20South">plantation</a> in Wytheville on September 21, 1907. He was buried in the East End Cemetery.
